text:
Email thread with Ivan Hermann & Chris Lilley:

Guys,

I do not know what the rules are on this (if any).

I  include a CSS style sheet to a standalone SVG file; this stylesheet
is  intended  to  be  used  *either*  from  SVG  *or* from XHTML. As a
consequence,  it  contains  selectors which are unknown in both cases:
eg,  'margin-left'  is used for the XHTML side but is unknown for SVG,
whereas  'fill'  is the other way round. I would expect that those are
simply ignored!

-  the  SVG  Adobe  plugin puts a message into the message area of the
browser but happily goes on. However
- batik gives an error message and simply stops processing!

I  would expect the Adobe behaviour to be more or less ok. But are
there rules here which I missed?

Ivan

============================================================================

On Sunday, June 30, 2002, 11:10:59 AM, Ivan wrote:

IH> Guys,

IH> I do not know what the rules are on this (if any).

Those in the CSS spec.

IH> I  include a CSS style sheet to a standalone SVG file; this stylesheet
IH> is  intended  to  be  used  *either*  from  SVG  *or* from XHTML.

Okay.

IH>  As a
IH> consequence,  it  contains  selectors which are unknown in both cases:
IH> eg,  'margin-left'


That is a property, not a selector.

IH> is used for the XHTML side but is unknown for SVG,
IH> whereas  'fill'  is the other way round.


Right.

IH> I would expect that those are
IH> simply ignored!

It would be better to look at what the CSS spec says rather than
expecting that things are ignored. In particular, the granularity of
what is ignored is important and is different for selectors,
properties, and property values.

IH> -  the  SVG  Adobe  plugin puts a message into the message area of the
IH> browser but happily goes on. However
IH> - batik gives an error message and simply stops processing!

Once the SVG validator is released, I expect Batik to stop giving hard
errors in cases where it should only issue a warning.

IH> I  would expect the Adobe behaviour to be more or less ok.

It is. The Batik behavior is also, in fact, ok too (see the second
link below).

IH> But are there rules here which I missed?

http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS2/conform.html#conformance
http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS2/conform.html#q3
http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS2/syndata.html#parsing-errors

-- 
 Chris                            mailto:chris@w3.org

==============================================================================

Chris,

Sorry,  I was indeed sloppy, I meant property (what mislead me is that
Adobe displays a message saying 'bad selector'). And I was also sloppy
in  another  respect: what Batik does is give an error message; if one
says   'ok',  then  it  would display the SVG file but it would ignore
other, valid CSS rules in the included file.

Having  said  that,  I  do not understand why you say Batik is ok,
too. The conformance section (thanks for the links) says:

"This  means that the user agent must accept all valid values and must
ignore declarations with invalid values."

and clearly this is not what happens.

Ivan
==============================================================================

On Sunday, June 30, 2002, 1:15:39 PM, Ivan wrote:

IH> Chris,

IH> Sorry,  I was indeed sloppy, I meant property (what mislead me is that
IH> Adobe displays a message saying 'bad selector').

OK, Adobe has a bad message there.

IH> And I was also sloppy
IH> in  another  respect: what Batik does is give an error message; if one
IH> says   'ok',  then  it  would display the SVG file but it would ignore
IH> other, valid CSS rules in the included file.

Well, Batik should not ignore other rules that are valid.

IH> Having  said  that,  I  do not understand why you say Batik is ok,

because I did not know what you just said, that it then ignored the
rest of the stylesheet.

IH> too. The conformance section (thanks for the links) says:

IH> "This  means that the user agent must accept all valid values and must
IH> ignore declarations with invalid values."

IH> and clearly this is not what happens.

Yes, that is now clear.
